content.question: At a large corporation, 6,000 employees from department A and 4,000 employees from department B are attending a training session. A random sample of 500 employees attending the session will be selected. Consider two sampling methods: with replacement and without replacement. How will the methods affect the standard deviations of the sampling distribution of the sample proportion of employees from department B?

choices.label: The standard deviations will be equal from either method.

Sampling without replacement will result in a standard deviation less than but close to <math alttext="the square root of the fraction 0.4 times 0.6 over 500 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.4</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>0.6</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Sampling without replacement will result in a standard deviation greater than but close to <math alttext="the square root of the fraction 0.4 times 0.6 over 500 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.4</mn><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>0.6</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Sampling with replacement will result in a standard deviation less than but close to <math alttext="the square root of the fraction 0.4 times 0.6 over 500 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.4</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>0.6</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Sampling with replacement will result in a standard deviation greater than but close to <math alttext="the square root of the fraction 0.4 times 0.6 over 500 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.4</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>0.6</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>.
